abstracts.cdata!:
Despite a satisfactory project outcome,
            sustainability is unlikely, and institutional development
            impacts were only modest; yet, performances were both rated
            satisfactory. A number of lessons convey the following,
            particularly, given the post-conflict situation in the
            country, and, reinforces previous lessons learned, including
            built-in project flexibility, appropriate donor
            coordination, and, provision of procurement and financial
            management training. Early intervention is critical to
            eliminating bottlenecks that could lead to lengthy delays in
            procurement, and/or approval of plans. Guidance needs to be
            specific and solution-oriented, not in the form of
            additional critique. Clients must be encouraged to be
            forthcoming upon encountering difficulties, which should be
            rewarded with advice that moves the project forward, not by
            criticism and threats. Concurrently, Supervision should be
            seen as an on-going, not just a semi-annual process.
            Frequent visits to the field reduce the" threat"
            factor to clients, and should be viewed as a support
            activity, not one where criticism is paramount. In addition,
            sub-sector programs need to be developed as part of broad
            systemic approaches - both in terms of financial
            availability to the sector, and in terms resulting from the
            contention forces between graduates within the system, and
            the demand for their skills within the labor force. The
            balance between expansion and quality is a difficult one to
            achieve: at mid-term it became apparent that an imbalance
            was in the making. While the Government took steps to
            redress the problem, donors could have recognized that
            over-emphasis on achieving enrollment targets at all costs,
            may well be counter productive. Nonetheless, establishing
            targets that are ambitious, may help preserve the validity
            of sector development plans.

abstracts.cdata!:
The first five-year phase of the
            Education Sector Development Project, an expenditure program
            to restructure and expand Ethiopia's educational
            system, improves overall educational attainment while
            achieving greater social equity. The project has six
            components. Basic education, the first, builds, upgrades,
            and renovates new primary schools, reforms curriculum,
            upgrades teachers, and increases textbooks in order to
            increase access and enrollment--especially in rural areas,
            improve teacher quality and school proximity. It uses
            non-formal education and radio programs. The second
            component expands secondary schools, revises curriculum,
            upgrades teachers, and increases instructional materials and
            equipment. The third component consists of technical and
            vocational education and training activities that encourage
            private sector participation in order to tie training to the
            job market, increase the availability of skilled labor, and
            raise the employment rate. The fourth component upgrades and
            expands teacher training institutes and colleges and uses
            distance learning. The fifth component expands higher
            education by encouraging private sector investment and
            designing cost-sharing schemes to meet the country's
            needs for educators, engineers, health workers, and public
            administrators. The sixth component, institutional
            development, improves planning, finance management, and
            implementation, monitoring, and evaluation capacities of the
            education ministries and agencies.
